messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> DanHinojosa wrote:
>
> > So, I have been a programmer for many years, but barely have I got
> > into TDD. One of the roadblocks I have gotten into is contexts.
> > There is no way to test them outside of an container or file system
> > when they are embedded into a method. Let me pick on an InitialContext
> > and VelocityContext in this email example:
>
> What are you trying to test? It looks like you're testing
> VelocityContext. Are you on the Velocity project? or just a user of
> Velocity? If it's the latter, then why are you testing Velocity?
>
> > VelocityContext context = new VelocityContext();
> > context.put("requestMap", requestMap);
> > StringWriter w = new StringWriter();
> > Velocity.mergeTemplate("mytemplate.vm", "UTF-8", context, w);
> > String text = w.toString();
>
> I use this as the basis for testing web page templates without serving
> them up from a web server. It works like a charm. I'd prefer a solution
> that doesn't touch the file system, but the effort required to bypass
> the file system might be too great, considering how I write page
> templates (in text files).
>
> > InitialContext ic = new InitialContext();
> > Session session = (Session) ic.find("mail/MailSource");
> > Message msg = new MimeMessage(session);
> > msg.setContent(text, "text/plain");
>
> Again, what are you testing here?
>
> I find that when I'm confused about whether or what to mock, or when I
> feel like I'm mocking too much, then I'm confused about what I'm
> testing. Step back, breathe, and point to the object in your test that
> you're testing. Once you do that, the path is quite clear. If it isn't,
> point it out to us and we'll help.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
> Your guide to software craftsmanship
> JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
>


I am not testing the VelocityContext, or an InitialContext. I am
testing my class that USES VelocityContext and the InitialContext.

Anyway, I think I got the problem solved for both the initial context
and the velocity context. As per the Velocity Context issue, I bought
some book called "JUnit Recipes" or something like that. It is a
pretty good book, you may have heard of it.
